fields.description:
Is it possible to add the filenames of a commit to the commit message automatically?

Maybe as a opt-in option.
fields.summary: Add filename to commit massage

fields.description:
Since I installed 1.6.4.1, I've noticed that the column I'm sorting by in 'Files in the working tree' keeps resetting itself to 'Filename'. I prefer to sort by 'Path' and I'm sure that in older versions, this preference was remembered between sessions.

Now, every time I open a repo window, I have to reclick the Path header to sort by that column again. This is annoying and a bit of a regression, I'm certain I didn't used to have to do this. Maybe this is a consequence of change SRCTREE-1440? Could this behaviour be put back to how it was before, where the previously sorted column is remembered?
fields.summary: Sort column in 'files in working tree' keeps resetting

fields.description:
When starting SourceTree you are presented with a "Welcome to SourceTree" bookmarks window if you have no existing repositories set up.
If you resize this window horizontally as small as it can go, then re-expand it, the text crops off, and the title improperly aligns right.
fields.summary: Bookmarks Window Resizes Improperly

fields.description:
Hi, one many projects i get the following error message in sourcetree on commit:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree commit -q -F /var/folders/_b/f54h3fdj2tl60yymlgb3zly00000gn/T/SourceTreeTemp.rEaW6x 
error: unable to create temporary file: File exists
error: Error building trees
Completed with errors, see above

If i commit the changes e.g in PHPStorm, I'm afterwards able to push the change to the remote endpoint.

Please fix this. I also had this problem with one version before.
fields.summary: Commiting is not possible due to existing temporary files

fields.description: Whenever I choose commit in a mercurial repository in 1.6.4.1, the commit dialog is always sorted by filename, even if it was set to sort by the "?" column (which i'll call file status) on the previous commit and in the the main window of the repo. In previous versions the commit dialog would remember it's sorting column (I think - if I am wrong about it remembering, at least it was always set to the "?" column, which would make sense - so that you can see the files you're about to commit at top if you have many untracked files in your repository). Always reverting to filename sorting in the commit dialog is inconvenient, because it often requires a re-sort of the list to easily see all the files you're about to commit.
fields.summary: Commit dialog sorting always reverts to filename

fields.description:
Consider this scenario. I know there's a bug on line 73 of file X, and I want to know why/when it was introduced, and who introduced it. The file isn't just 'available' from SourceTree. I'd have to change the filters in the file views to show it. Alternatively I do a search for that file name in the search. Once I've gotten the file I then do a "Blame selected" and go to the line in question which is a problem. The blame screen doesn't allow me to a) go to a line number or b) search for some text. I then have to "View in log window".

Look at ways of improving this process. Perhaps just improving the blame window so you can jump to lines or search for text, and also a 'quick open' feature (Cmd+T) to open a specific file for blaming/logging. This would greatly enhance discovery of changes in files.
fields.summary: Better discovery for specific lines / quick open feature?

fields.description: Need to support more recent versions of Mercurial. This needs lots of testing and can't go out in the next major version, but perhaps a minor version if a beta deploy went out first for users.
fields.summary: Upgrade embedded Git/Mercurial versions + add support for later hg versions

fields.description:
I find the space allocated for writing commit messages is much too small.

I can't find any part of the UI to "grab" so I can expand the area for the commit message. Neither have I been able to find a relevant preference.

I'd prefer that:

\\
* I could "grab" the bottom of the text box that contains the commit message and drag it to expand the area.
\\ \\
* The GUI remembered my preference from commit to commit.
\\ \\
fields.summary: Expandable space for commit messages

fields.description: When using SourceTree on OS X Lion+ it's nice to have the current repository your working in full screen.  If you want to start working on another repository you have to open up bookmarks and then open up a new window for that repository which is quite awkward.  It would be nice to be able to switch current window to a different repository.  This would be a much more natural way to work in OS X using full screen mode.
fields.summary: Full screen switch repository

fields.description:
I'd like to (even repeatedly) be able to donate to SourceTree - it's just amazing. 

1) donation button - put it somewhere and gather donations

or 2) make different types of registration like - Free and a Supporter, which have exactly the same features, but the latter has donated money
fields.summary: A built-in donate button

fields.description:
I'd like an option for the bookmark list to indicate the presence of stashes.

If I right-click on a bookmark, and hover over "View Options" in the resulting menu, I see a number of options I can turn on or off. I'd like it if one of the options turned on/off an indicator that repositories contain stashes.
fields.summary: Indicate stash presence in bookmark

fields.description:
For each of my projects there's always the main project file that I want to find quickly and double click so that the OS opens it in my development IDE.

To find the file quicker I always enter in the file's extension of either '.rbvcp' or '.xojo_project', or '.sh', etc.

It would be really convenient if I could selectively save the search strings for use the next time I use SourceTree. Then I could just select that saved search filter and save time typing.
fields.summary: Save Search String Filter

fields.description:
I was attempting to use the OS X keyboard shortcut preferences to map a keyboard shortcut to "Resolve Conflicts>Launch External Merge Tool" but it was not working. 

It would be nice if there were a way in the sourcetree settings to define a keyboard shortcut for that (and other) menu options, since navigating to it for every file is very inefficient.
fields.summary: Ability to define/customize keyboard shortcuts

fields.description: the git log in log sheet is always in red color, It's make me nervous cause the red may told people something wrong, could sourcetree take some improvement about the color, thanks a lot
fields.summary: Change the Color of git log

fields.description: There's no border around the diff view on the apply patch sheet
fields.summary: Add border on the create patch sheet

fields.description:
HI,when  I click right mouse button in the [File staged in the inbox] area
if  clicked at space area such as area blow the folders in the eara commit is gray, i can not commit anything.
if clicked at any file or folder , the commit menu in right pop menu is black and ok, please see the attached file, thx for a excellent app
fields.summary: Disable 'Commit' when no files select in context-click of staged/unstaged area

fields.description:
HI,when  I click right mouse button in the [File staged in the inbox] area
if  clicked at space area such as area blow the folders in the eara commit is gray, i can not commit anything.
if clicked at any file or folder , the commit menu in right pop menu is black and ok, please see the attached file, thx for a excellent app
fields.summary: is must choose file or folder in stage area, then can commit file suitable

fields.description:
During an interactive rebase stree_gri crashes with the following:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree -c sequence.editor='/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' -c core.editor='/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' rebase --continue
2013-08-26 09:48:14.315 stree_gri[10832:707] *** Terminating app due to uncaught exception 'NSInvalidArgumentException', reason: '-[__NSCFString hasPrefix:]: nil argument'
*** First throw call stack:
(
	0   CoreFoundation                      0x00007fff8fbe2b06 __exceptionPreprocess + 198
	1   libobjc.A.dylib                     0x00007fff862b23f0 objc_exception_throw + 43
	2   CoreFoundation                      0x00007fff8fbe28dc +[NSException raise:format:] + 204
	3   CoreFoundation                      0x00007fff8fba4b1a -[__NSCFString hasPrefix:] + 90
	4   stree_gri                           0x00000001000015c8 stree_gri + 5576
	5   stree_gri                           0x00000001000010f4 stree_gri + 4340
)
libc++abi.dylib: terminate called throwing an exception
error: /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri died of signal 6
error: There was a problem with the editor '/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri'.
Please supply the message using either -m or -F option.
Could not commit staged changes.

I had just resolved a merge conflict, clicked commit, and picked "Continue Rebase".
fields.summary: Interactive rebase fails w/ stree_gri crash

fields.description: When a submodule is updated the ST notifications report back with the submodule path in the notification and then prompt to clone the submodule. We probably should check if that path that's brought back matches a submodule in any added repositories before making any notification.
fields.summary: Submodule notifications report repo paths for non-added repos

fields.description: When removing unversioned files, move them to Trash instead of deleting them forever. And since the remove actions becomes reversible, don't show a confirmation dialog when removing unversioned files. I'd also recommend naming the action "Move to Trash" instead of "Remove"
fields.summary: Remove unversioned files to trash

fields.description:
A nice feature available on Windows version of Sourcetree is the repository tabs.

Could be very interesting if this feature become available to Mac users too.

Cheers,
Lucas Lima
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Add the repository tabs as on Windows version.
When using Submodules "Fetch" should also fetch submodules
Ability to commit and tag that commit at the same time

fields.description:
It would be very useful and convenient if the list of local branches on the left-hand side could visually indicate that a branch is tracking a remote branch. Currently you can only find out if this is the case by right-clicking and seeing if a tracked remote branch is mentioned.

The reason this is useful to me is that we work in combination with bitbucket pull requests quite often, where a branch is deleted when the pull request is merged. Although the remote branch is of course removed from my git repo when hitting fetch, I would like to quickly see which corresponding local branches I can get rid of.
fields.summary: Visual indication of local branch tracking remote

fields.description: Sometimes some lines of code are too long and sourcetree will show horizontal scrollbar.  I believe some people will prefer having wordwrap.
fields.summary: Wordwrap in diff view.

fields.description: If a Mercurial repository in SourceTree contains a tag with a name including a forward slash, it will result in SourceTree thinking the tag itself is a tree-structure and cause it to display rather weird.
fields.summary: Forward Slashes in Mercurial Tags Cause Weirdness in Listing

fields.description:
To provide autocompletion suggestion from filenames and words in the commit screen.

(See tortoiseSVN for example.)
fields.summary: Autocomplete Commit Log

fields.description:
Running 'stree' without any parameters from the terminal does two things. Firstly it opens a new instance of SourceTree even if one's running. Secondly it assumes the current path is the repository to open.

Take a look into making SourceTree just open if it isn't already and not opening any bookmarks etc.
fields.summary: stree from terminal with no parameters

fields.description: An indicator that the file is empty (and thus probably isn't a binary) would be useful.  Granted, this information is not provided by Git status either (At least not for untracked files), but my hopeful goal with sourcetree is not having to open a terminal window to double-check.
fields.summary: Zero byte size (or empty) files are reported as "binary files" with "no preview available" and no indication that they are 0-bytes

fields.description:
Working in a collaborative environment, I basically never ever need to have my user login added to a submodule reference when I create one.
If I'm not extra careful with that, it's then pushed to remote with my login, which my teammates don't usually enjoy at their next pull.

It would be great to add this as a user preference not to add the login by default.
fields.summary: Add Git submodule without user account detail by default

fields.description: Move the branches/tags into their own categories and sort them in the jump to bar.
fields.summary: Sort the 'jump to' drop-down and categorise

fields.description: The command output should be in reverse order with the most recent entries being added on top
fields.summary: Reverse order of command output

fields.description:
Comment from SRCTREE-1692 by Eugene:

"Is it possible to make this configurable or to disable window restoration altogether?
Most often I use SourceTree via the command-line helper, so when I run "stree <dir>", I already know what repository I want to work with, and I don't need extraneous windows (e.g. my previously opened repositories or bookmarks) to pop up.
Upd. That's an unfortunate reason that keeps me on SourceTree 1.5, because there this issue isn't yet fixed, and I can keep replacing "~/Library/Application Support/SourceTree/openWindowList" with an empty openWindowList file before actually running "stree", so that everything works as I'd like to."

Note, window restoration to be disabled, however running 'stree <path>' should open just that single repository window and nothing else.
fields.summary: Disable window restoration altogether option

fields.description:
I was on develop and needed to stash my changed files.  When I tried to stash, I got the error "Stash Exists.  A stash with this name already exists".

I left the message field blank as SourceTree will set the stash name to "WIP on [branch]" then append the parent's short hash and description.  

It appears that git or SourceTree is only looking at the first part of the stash name (up to the colon).  I already had a "WIP on develop" stash but it also had a hash/desc appended to it.  Only by adding a message (in the attached pic, I just entered 'z'), which set the stash name to "On develop: [message]" would it then stash properly.
fields.summary: Stash Exists error with empty message

fields.description:
When using git flow, I've started a release and when I finish it, it gives me fatal errors regarding 'origin'.

I named my remote 'Bitbucket' instead of origin (I was supposed to setup multiple remotes but just haven't yet) and I think that is causing the issue.  Is SourceTree or git flow hardcoded to only push to a remote named origin during the finish?

Since there isn't an ongoing log in this version (but looks to be in 1.7, yea!) I'm not sure exactly what is going on when the git flow release finish command is running.

After the release is finished (merge release to master, merge release to develop) then it fails when pushing these changes to the remote.  I can dismiss the error dialog box then manually push to the remote and everything is good again.

Attached is a screenshot showing the error.
Also note the last line.  Shouldn't that be "FROM develop TO origin"?

Hope this helps
fields.summary: git flow release finish requires origin?
Last update has reverted by SourceTree to an eval version

fields.description: Following up on SRCTREE-1127, having SourceTree available on Linux would be great.
fields.summary: SourceTree for Linux

fields.description: Currently the signed details are only shown on commits and not tags. Beside each tag there could be a 'lock' icon either on the log row or in the commit details (or both)
fields.summary: Show signing details on tags

fields.description: Make the release notes easier to read, the font is too small.
fields.summary: Release notes legibility

fields.description:
As reported here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/92976/external-diff-command-won-t-launch-araxis-merge?page=1#comment-200863

This means newer versions of Araxis won't work from SourceTree. Neither can we assume that 'compare2' exists so need some kind of fallback in the event 'compare' isn't found (use a different script dynamically, perhaps?)
fields.summary: Araxis have changed their utility to 'compare2'. We assume 'compare'

fields.description:
Add the ability to delete all merged branches.

In our workflow, we develop on feature branches and then use Stash to perform code reviews and merge to master (nothing new or unusual there).

If one has done a number of independent feature branches (and the number of concurrent features can stack up once you factor in that it takes some time for others to review, approve and merge), then the number of branches quickly adds up.  Stash has an option to automatically delete the branch on 'origin' once they're merged - but that leaves the branches still on the developers machines.

Every so often, one must go and check that each branch has been merged, and if it has, go and delete it.

It would be useful if Stash could do this automatically.  It already has an option to prune remote branches that no longer exist.  Perhaps that is a useful place to include the option of deleting local branches that have been merged.
fields.summary: Add ability to delete all merged branches.

fields.description:
Including Git Flow is awesome, but would it be possible to use the Git Flow AVH fork (https://github.com/petervanderdoes/gitflow)?

The original Git Flow hasn't been updated in nearly a year now as where the AVH fork is constantly seeing new releases containing both fixes and features.

It functions exactly the same and should be a drop in replacement.
fields.summary: Switch to git-flow-avh

fields.description: You can use the attached two files as comparisons. They're just text with key/value pairs so you can easily compare the two. Where there's '%@' or some equivalent such as '%1$@' means they're substituted for some text.
fields.summary: Japanese Translation Updates in August 2013

fields.description: We could actually do this by calling 'gpg --verify'  as spoken of in the following: https://www.kernel.org/pub//software/scm/git/docs/git-diff-tree.html
fields.summary: Add ability to verify signatures

fields.description: Add an icon with a key to commits which are signed to make it much clearer which are safe and secure.
fields.summary: Add a 'key' symbol to signed commits/tags

fields.description: Lately I noticed that SourceTree has been eating up my CPU and it's getting slower on my git repositories. I only have 2 active repositories and every time I want to commit / fetch it's taking ages (cpu usage can peak up to 300% - see screenshots)
fields.summary: High cpu usage during refresh

fields.description:
I almost always only want to se curren branch.
So when switching branch,
I am often suprised that it contains commits that were in another branch,
when it actually doesn't - it is showing all branches.

This has lead to some errors,
so it would be a much needed feature.
fields.summary: Keep the choice of show (All branches/Curren branch) when switching between branches

fields.description:
Separate from the other report, this one's occurring regardless of the fetch, but we need to check the background fetch isn't having an impact on the memory consumption also.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/149345/source-tree-1-5-7-1-memory-leaks?sort=votes&page=2

Reaching 6GB on memory usage for a user according to the AAC issue. More details to follow.
fields.summary: Memory leak

fields.description:
When using SourceTree (at least with Mercurial) top branches panel (gray color) shows closed branches and does not show all currently open actual branches.

See attached screenshot.
fields.summary: Incorrect branch list in top branches panel (using Mercurial)

fields.description: I need a night mode layout, i.e. in XCode I use Midnight Theme, with black background, and colorful textcolor. In development it is really useful. It protects eyes. Source tree should have it also.
fields.summary: night mode

fields.description: I use an iMac 27, the sourcetree's log view font is too small to read on screen and I cannot change the default font and font's size.
fields.summary: ability to change the log view's font

fields.description: When pushing to or pulling from github.com remote branch, the Mac OS password dialog periodically is displayed. This is despite the option "store password in keychain" being checked each time.
fields.summary: Password required dialog for github.com password continues to be displayed

fields.description:
Pointing the browser to https://sourcetreeapp.com/ instead of http://sourcetreeapp.com/ will land you on the Torus Knot Software page.
It does mention SourceTree, and points to www.sourcetreeapp.com, so all is well, but it might confuse and/or scare people expecting to land on an Atlassian page.
fields.summary: https://sourcetreeapp.com/ redirects to Torus Knot page

fields.description: I am a relatively new user of both git and Sourcetree. I stashed my changes in a project for the first time, and I found myself stumped on how to reapply the stashed changes. Google was no help, and there was no mention in the help documentation. Perhaps adding just an optional toolbar button to run 'git stash pop'? Just to help those new to the whole idea and the Sourcetree gui.
fields.summary: Might I suggest an 'unstash' or 'stash pop' button be available for the toolbar?

fields.description: When the feature/hotfix is done and it is about to be finished it would be nice to have an option to squash the rebased feature/hotfix. Thanks to that feature will be propagated to the development branch as a single commit (when history is not necessary).
fields.summary: Squash option on finishing feature/hotfix dialog

fields.description:
As requested here (see conversation): http://twitter.com/sLoPPydrive/status/362477627291860992
Basically user wants to be able to pull across a merge commit into another branch, which requires the --mainline option to pick a parent to compare to. The user must be able to pick one parent commit of the merge (remember octopus merges) to use this option.
fields.summary: Add support for --mainline option when cherry-picking

fields.description: Feature sync: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREEWIN-880
fields.summary: Add support for --mainline in cherry pick (Mac)

fields.description:
In my company's CI setup, each developer have its own git repo that is monitored by the CI server and built whenever a push occurs. Any sub-project can be push on this repo, hence it is added as a remote to the different local repositories we are using. At a given time its history might have nothing to do with the current's repo one so the main history view in source tree gets polluted.

What I would like is the possibility to completely hide all the branches of any remote from the main view.
fields.summary: As a user I'd like to be able to hide one remote's branches

fields.description: SourceTree should be able to delete branches that start with a minus/hyphen/dash as this is possible from the command line.
fields.summary: Possibility to Delete Badly Named Branches

fields.description: Trying to clone a git repo from Stash. If an invalid password is entered too many times, the authentication would eventually fails and give no other chance to authenticate.
fields.summary: Connection to Stash fails after too many tries (CAPTCHA prompt causes failure)

fields.description: When trying to clone git repos from hosted services (BitBucket, Stash,...) there is no clear warning message if the connection is failing because the error message entered is invalid
fields.summary: No clear error message when password is invalid

fields.description:
Purely for the sake of convenience, it would be really nice to just have a quick unstash button. The most common need I have for stashing is to switch branches and then reapply the stash to another branch. Currently I can quickly stash the branch, but then I have to scroll down the list, right click and choose unstash to restore it.

Note that SRCTREE-1377 is a duplicate of this request, but in that case the requester didn't know how to unstash. In my case, I think this would just be a more useful feature.
fields.summary: Add an "Unstash" or "Stash Pop" button in the toolbar

fields.description:
The “discard” button in the preview pane, when viewing a file in the working copy, does not behave as expected (and can result in data loss).

I had staged some changes to a file, and then continued to work on the file.  I later decided to throw out the unstaged changes and revert to the staged copy.  With the file selected in the working copy pane, I decided that rather than click each of the “discard hunk” buttons, I would instead click the “discard” button at the top of the preview pane, inferring that this would discard all hunks.  I did so, and was dismayed to find the file reset to HEAD—all of my staged changes were also thrown away.

In retrospect I realize I could have chosen “reset” in the contextual menu against the file in the working copy.  However, the individual “discard hunk” buttons cause a reset (to stage, not to HEAD), and a reasonable person would presume that the parent “discard” button would behave similarly, but at the scope of the whole file.

Of course, were I examining a file in the stage (rather than the working copy), I would expect this action to reset to HEAD.

The behaviour of the preview pane's file-level “discard” button, when examining a file in the working copy, should cause a reset to stage, not to HEAD.
fields.summary: “Discard” button in working copy also blows away the stage

fields.description:
In the GitHub app for Mac, there is a "Sync" button that essentially performs a Pull with fast-forward merge and a Push immediately after if no conflicts occurs. If a conflict occurs during the merge, the sync operation is stopped. Most our users on our team only ever work on the master branch, and as such, they never push without pulling first.

I suggest a checkbox labelled "Pull with fast-forward merge" on the Push dialog. If that is checked, then uncommited changes will stop the operation, and if there are any changes to pull, then perform a pull with fast-forward merge. And if there were no conflicts, then finally perform the push.

(I am looking for a GitHub app alternative for our team. Some of us are power users and others could care less about the differences between SVN and Git. I am hoping that SourceTree, with some convenience options, can satisfy both parties.)
fields.summary: add a "pull with fast-forward merge" option on push dialog

fields.description:
I found that the GitHub app for Mac is very streamlined for our team. If we create a new Branch or perform a Pull, the GitHub app will automatically stash changes before and apply sttash changes afterwards. Creating branches and pulling on unstaged/unstashed working copy are very common operations.

Can you guys add a checkbox for "automatically stash changes" on the dialogs for creating a new branch and performing a pull? And have that checkbox remember it's last setting.

(I am looking for a GitHub app alternative for our team. Some of us are power users and others could care less about the differences between SVN and Git. I am hoping that SourceTree, with some convenience options, can satisfy both parties.)
fields.summary: add option to automatically stash changes

fields.description:
It would be really nice to be able to have iCloud support to sync the bookmarks across multiple computers. It would only need to sync the bookmarks and locations (but settings are nice too) through iCloud.

If the location doesn't exist on the computer maybe offer them a new location. Either way the location of the projects should be the same across all the machines.
fields.summary: iCloud Support for Bookmarks

fields.description:
If a user hasn't pushed a commit then we still show a warning when amending a commit. User makes a valid point, we should only really show it if they've pushed their changes.

Need to double check the safety of ascertaining pushed commits first and foremost as Git has quirks sometimes on its certainty of commit state.
fields.summary: Don't show amend commit warning on non-pushed commits

fields.description: Support renaming of folders. Currently only support renaming of files.
fields.summary: Folder renames

fields.description:
Please add ability to auto-pull commits from default repository for (selected for auto pool) branch in background in case if they are not producing conflicts and/or if there are no uncommited changes in selected branch and/or there are no changes in selected branch.

Using Hg Flow, I would like to auto-pull commits in background for "develop" branch.
fields.summary: Auto-pulling in background

fields.description:
Localizable strings files for Mac/iOS projects - can you please fix the difference panel, to show show (as visible text) differences in localizable strings files? This would make a *huge* difference to the product! :) ... hence why I've marked as "Major".

The panel simply reports as e.g. a "Modified binary file", and displays the text "No Preview Available".
fields.summary: Localizable strings files - show differences as text!

fields.description: When I create a new branch by clicking on the "branch" button very often I'll want to create a branch with a similar name to the one I'm branching from. I would find it useful if the "current" branch field would let you select text so that you can copy it.
fields.summary: Create a new branch - copy current branch name

fields.description:
I am maintaining 30+ git repositories by now, which does make the current bookmarks list relatively useless. I end up using the build-in filter all the time. I think it would be great if bookmarks could appear in a desktop-like fashion, as icons with nested folders and such. That would allow for much more powerful grouping and faster access to individual repos.

P.S. The rest of the tool works perfect for me, so thanks a lot!
fields.summary: Better Bookmarks organization

fields.description:
use git init to turn an empty directory into a git repo

create and commit 2 files (main.h and main.c) into the master branch

delete one of the files

switch back to SourceTree... 

Expect: Icon change to indicate the file is missing on disk

Actual: No indication that one of the files is now missing on disk.
fields.summary: Track files not reporting missing in the GUI

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Set up a GitHub Enterprise instance with SSL, self-signed certificate and in "private mode" (all users must authenticate).
# Create a repository in GitHub Enterprise.
# Start SourceTree and clone that repository.
# [SourceTree will prompt to accept the self-signed certificate|^screenshot1.png].
# [Clicking "Accept" will make the activity spinner spin forever|^screenshot2.png].
# [Clicking "Cancel" on the "Clone Repository" dialog and re-trying to clone the same repository will accept the self-signed certificate and prompt to authenticate|^screenshot3.png].
fields.summary: SourceTree Blocks After Accepting Self-Signed Certificate From GitHub Enterprise

fields.description:
The binary available from http://www.sourcetreeapp.com/ does not provide a way to verify the DMG or its contents. There is no MD5 or SHA-1 hash available to validate the image file.

There is also no OpenPGP-compatible signature available to verify:

1. The image file.
2. The SourceTree app.
3. The verification hashes, which are not available (see above).

This is a blocker for deployment in a security-conscious enterprise environment. Expected behavior for an enterprise-class application is that the authenticity of the binary can be established prior to installation or deployment.

This problem could easily be solved by publishing MD5 or SHA-1 hashes for the binary, along with a public key signature to validate the hashes and the binary itself.
fields.summary: Sourcetree for Mac doesn't provide signatures or hashes for verification

fields.description:
The SourceTree EULA (available [here|https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=3&ved=0CDkQFjAC&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsourcetreeapp.com%2Feula.rtf&ei=xovuUYuoFeST0QWpp4CIDg&usg=AFQjCNGbHEJerNzwvcRsFqyIXJWzR6tyvg&sig2=PAwENd8TeT8QaoRGBxurfg&bvm=bv.49478099,d.d2k]) has the following text:
{quote}
1. GRANT OF LICENSE.
 The SOFTWARE PRODUCT is licensed as follows: 
(a) Installation and Use. Atlassian grants you the right to install and use copies of the SOFTWARE PRODUCT on your computer running a validly licensed copy of the operating system for which the SOFTWARE PRODUCT was designed. 'Validly licensed' means the following:
 (i) For evaluation, using the software for up to 30 days free of charge, or 
(ii) After purchasing a single license, using the software on a single computer, OR
 using the software on multiple computers so long as it is the same person using it (b) Backup Copies. You may also make copies of the SOFTWARE PRODUCT as may be necessary for backup and archival purposes.
{quote}

This does not seem appropriate for a free product and should be updated.
fields.summary: Update EULA For Free License

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Set up a GitHub Enterprise Instance.
# Create a repository.
# Clone Repository in SourceTree.

SourceTree will identify the repository as coming from a Subversion server.
fields.summary: SourceTree Identifies Git Repositories From GitHub Enterprise as SVN Repositories

fields.description: Entering a password containing " when registering SourceTree causes a JSON error
fields.summary: Registering SourceTree doesn't accept password with " in it

fields.description: When I click on the SorceTree icon (on the dock) the App starts but no window opens. I have to click twice to open the SourceTree window.
fields.summary: SourceTree Window Does Not Open When Clicking the Icon

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Create a bookmark to a repository.
# Move the repository to another location outside of SourceTree with a different name, e.g. from the command line.
# SourceTree reports "Repository moved or deleted".
# Attempting to open the repo results in "Repository Missing" dialog, with "Change folder", "Cancel", "Remove Bookmark" buttons.
# Change folder to the new location.
# Open the repository in SourceTree.
# The name of the repository as it appears in the repository window title, is still the old path, which is no longer valid.
# Closing and re-opening the repository window does not resolve this, but restarting SourceTree does.
fields.summary: Missing Repository Name Is Not Updated After Correction

fields.description:
It seems that the production branch needs to exist before initialising git-flow.

May I suggest then that this just be documented?

In particular, in the help section "Initialising a repository for Git Flow / Hg Flow" it states:

Git Flow initialisation

On initialising, Git Flow will ensure that the production branch (e.g. 'master') and the development branch (e.g. 'develop') already exist, or it will create them.
fields.summary: Document Git Flow initialisation

fields.description:
I'm not sure whether this is normal git behaviour or not. But either way, it would be good if Source Tree wrapped the behaviour, and/or provided an option.

Example:
 - Branch A has a submodule S
 - Branch B does not have any submodules

When switching from A to B, my working copy fills with all the files from S, as new unstaged files. When I remove them, and switch back to A, it's even worse: I have to go into the submodule and reset the deletion of all of its files again.

It would be great if either Source Tree handled this automatically, or if necessary, it asked me what I'd like to do each time.
fields.summary: When switching branches that do/do not have a submodule, files are left behind

fields.description:
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-671

When there's an SSL certificate problem we just don't report any projects. This is probably because we can't parse the message and it's also probably reporting 'success' rather than an error. We should check if the project list is empty first and if that's true then check if it contains "SSL error" or something along those lines.

Check the output from the linked issue above. This way we can report back to the user something more meaningful.
fields.summary: SSL certificate issue for Stash causes projects to not be displayed

fields.description:
Let the user specify the width of the commit message and SourceTree force that width. Useful for projects like Linux or Git as they're very strict on commit message formats.

Submitted via AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/191349/edit-long-commit-message
fields.summary: Hard-wrapping text in commit message

fields.description:
When selecting a few lines to stage, the button "Stage selected lines" only shows across the bottom of the code hunk which is often off-screen. Scrolling back and forth causes the user to lose track.

I suggest showing a button contextually in the top-right corner of the selected code lines for this purpose instead of the button at the bottom.
fields.summary: Show "stage selected lines" in context

fields.description:
When select System GIT version 1.8.X and restart Sourcetree 1.6.2.2, font problem occurred in description/Log View.

you can check the problem in attached image.
fields.summary: when using GIT 1.8.3.2, font problem in description/Log View

fields.description: Would be neat to have the option to specify `--recurse-submodules` for git-pull.
fields.summary: Allow to specify `--recurse-submodules` when pulling git repos

fields.description:
Safari was getting slow, so I fired up Activity Monitor to try to sample it and see what was happening. I immediately noticed the attached screenshot. SourceTree was clearly leaking memory, using over 5GiB of RPRVT. Beating mds at leaking memory is not easy. :-)

I have it set to "Check default remotes for updates every 10m". All projects are git.

Sorry that I didn't think to try any diagnosis, but I was paging out on a machine with 48GiB of RAM, so I was more about exiting processes instead of debugging why.
fields.summary: memory leak

fields.description:
Git 1.8.2 (I think) added the the ability to track specific branches in submodules, but Sourcetree only seems to partly support it.

Specifically, when you do "Add Submodule..." I see that the command is called with the "\-b" option and the branch specified (if you use the advanced settings). However, when you "Pull" from the parent repository it always executes "git submodule update \-\-recursive \-\-init". This will always put the submodule back to the commit stored with the parent repository. If the "\-\-remote" argument is also supplied, it will first pull the given branch to the submodule.

At some level this is as simple as adding "\-\-remote" to the submodule update command, although I'm sure everyone would like the ability to set this on a per-submodule basis (so some submodules can be semi-static, referring to a specific commit unless specifically changed).
fields.summary: submodule branch tracking

fields.description:
When integrating code, my team's process requires copying the log from pushing to the remote. Unfortunately if I don't catch the log fast enough it disappears with no way for me to get that information. So I have turned on "Always display full console output", but I find that it displays the log output way too often. For instance when staging and unstaging files and it interrupts my workflow. 

I only want the log when pushing or pulling so that I can see when the state changes and optionally copy that to a ticket. An option to see the previous console message would be helpful as well.
fields.summary: Allow showing only push/pull log messages

fields.description: It is often useful for me to edit a previous commit's content rather than just the message. Gitx for instance, shows all the changes of the previous commit when in amend mode and lets you unstage changes from that commit. This is incredibly useful for removing a change that shouldn't have been in that commit and makes amending much more flexible.
fields.summary: Allow editing commit content when amending commit.

fields.description: As per discussion with jn/ss
fields.summary: Show friendly messages on HTML error return from API calls

fields.description:
Please make it impossible for the file list to be totally hidden because it can be confusing and difficult to retrieve.

See attached video for an illustration
fields.summary: File list is hidden

fields.description: No status update until finished cloning (lead to misunderstood that the cloning is not happening when repo is considerably large)
fields.summary: Progress Bar not working when cloning/pulling from repo

fields.description:
SourceTree v1.6.2.1 on Mac OSX v10.8.3

Interactive Rebase works well in non-git-submodule repositories, but when I try to do so on a git-submodule repository, it errors out:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c sequence.editor='/Users/jeff/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' -c core.editor='/Users/jeff/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' rebase -i --autosquash 
Could not execute editor

A dialog box with a text edit box labeled "Enter commit message" appears, and although I do not know what happens if I were to input something, clicking the dialog "Commit" button without any input text then gives me the following:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c sequence.editor='/Users/jeff/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' -c core.editor='/Users/jeff/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri' rebase -i --autosquash 
Rebasing (17/17)
Successfully rebased and updated refs/heads/dev.
Completed successfully

No changes are made to the git repository as expected, but no interactive rebase dialog as I did hope for.

You can (hopefully!) reproduce this bug by cloning a copy of the TTcards repository at https://github.com/i8degrees/ttcards and attempting to interactively rebase any of the git-submodules -- json_spirit, nomJSON, gamelib. Note that it (should) work inside the base repository (TTcards).

Thank you for your efforts,
Jeff

P.S. I find little reason to use the git command line now with this new feature :-D
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase Bug On a Submodule

fields.description:
When you press the Git flow button in sourcetree, and you forget to commit, you will get a message telling you to do so.

But, when you commit then, and again hit the git flow button, you don't have the option anymore to create the develop branch etc. 
You must start a feature/hotfix/release right away.

But when you do that, you will get the message that you must do a git flow init first.

Since the git flow init doesnt work in my terminal, it would be nice to still have the option available where you can init the git flow from within sourcetree after the commit.
fields.summary: Git flow fails when not committing

fields.description:
# Open a repository that has a master branch
# Initialise repository for git flow
# For Production branch change "master" to "production"
# For Development branch change "develop" to "master"
# Click OK
# From Repository menu select "Start New Release" under "Git flow / Hg flow"
# Enter a release and click OK
EXPECT: Release branch created
ACTUAL: error
{noformat}
git release start v1
fatal: Not a gitflow-enabled repo yet. Please run "git flow init" first.
Completed with errors, see above
{noformat}

NOTE: the configuration file does not look right:

{noformat}
[gitflow "branch"]
	master = master
	develop = master
{noformat}

But the same error occurs after changing this to:

{noformat}
[gitflow "branch"]
	master = production
	develop = master
{noformat}

Initialising git flow with the defaults does work.
fields.summary: git flow fails to initialize with non-default production and development branches

fields.description: When pushing to a remote branch from a current branch, when current branch tracks different remote branch, the push confirmation screen reverts to name of local branch.
fields.summary: Remote preserved in push confirmation screen

fields.description:
The left hand panel contains sections for BRANCHES, TAGS, REMOTES, STASHES and SUBMODULES.

I constantly right click on the branch from the BRANCHES list and expect to be able to find a 'branch' option.  I then realise my mistake and click on the 'Branch' button on the toolbar.

It seems logical (at least to me) to include a 'Branch' right click menu item on the BRANCHES list.
fields.summary: Add "BRANCHES" right click option to create a branch from the selected branch

fields.description: Add option to install software update on quit (like Adium) so I don't have to break my workflow and still get the update.
fields.summary: Add "Install on Quit" option for updates
